questions.text: Which type of microscopy uses an opaque disc to block light that would enter the objective lens directly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Darkfield microscopy

•	Darkfield microscopy uses an opaque disc to create a dark background and highlights the specimen.

questions.text: What is the function of the bacterial capsule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Protection from phagocytosis

•	 The bacterial capsule protects bacteria from being engulfed by phagocytes.

questions.text: Which phase of bacterial growth is characterized by rapid cell division?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Log phase

•	The log phase is marked by rapid bacterial replication and population increase.

questions.text: Which type of bacteria does not requires oxygen for growth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Obligate anaerobic bacteria

•	Obligate anaerobic bacteria does not require oxygen to grow.

questions.text: What is the most effective method for sterilizing surgical instruments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Autoclaving

•	Autoclaving uses steam under pressure to achieve sterilization.

questions.text: Which type of culture media is used to grow fastidious organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Enriched media

•	Enriched media contain additional nutrients to support the growth of fastidious organisms.

questions.text: Which method is used to isolate pure bacterial cultures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Streak plate method

•	The streak plate method is used to isolate individual colonies from a mixed culture.

questions.text: Which of the following processes involves the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium to another through direct contact?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Conjugation

•	Conjugation is a process where genetic material is transferred from one bacterium (donor) to another (recipient) through direct contact, often mediated by a sex pilus.

questions.text: Which of the following cells are primarily involved in the innate immune response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Macrophages  

•	Macrophages are a type of white blood cell that engulfs and digests cellular debris, foreign substances, microbes, and cancer cells. 

•	They are a crucial part of the innate immune system.

questions.text: The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules present peptides to which type of cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cytotoxic T cells  

•	MHC class I molecules present endogenously synthesized peptides to cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells).

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anaphylaxis  

•	Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate reactions mediated by IgE antibodies, such as anaphylaxis and allergies.

questions.text: Which cell surface marker is characteristic of helper T cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CD4  

•	CD4 is a glycoprotein found on the surface of helper T cells, which is crucial for their role in immune signalling.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in autoimmune diseases such as Graves’ disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type II 

•	Graves disease belongs to type II HSR.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of adaptive immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Specificity for antigens  

•	Adaptive immunity is characterized by its specificity for particular antigens and the ability to remember and respond more effectively upon re-exposure.

questions.text: Ouchterlony test is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Two dimensions double diffusion

•	Ouchterlony test is immunodiffusion test – Two dimension – Double diffusion test.

questions.text: A 45yearold male presents with fever, chills, and a productive cough with rust coloured sputum. Gram staining of the sputum shows in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Streptococcus pneumoniae

•	Lanceolate or flame shaped Gram positive Diplococci Suggestive of Strep pneumoniae.

•	Rusty sputum is characteristic of pneumococcal pneumoniae.

questions.text: A 30yearold woman presents with dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and suprapubic pain. A urine culture grows a gramnegative rod that is lactose fermenting. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Escherichia coli

•	E. coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infections and is a gramnegative rod that ferments lactose and motile.

•	Staph. saprophyticus is commonly causes UTI in sexually active young women.

questions.text: A patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fever and a new heart murmur. Blood cultures are positive for gram positive cocci in clusters which is coagulase Positive.  What is the selective medium for this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MSA

•	Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of endocarditis in intravenous drug users and appears as gram positive cocci in clusters and 
Coagulase positive.

•	Selective medium  Mannitol Salt Agar and Ludlam medium.

questions.text: A 25yearold male presents with severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture reveals gram negative Lens shaped diplococci. What is the important virulent factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polysaccharide capsule

•	Neisseria meningitidis is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis, particularly in young adults, and appears as gram negative lens shaped diplococci

•	Main Virulent factor is polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: Choose the correct selective medium for Bacillus cereus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MYPPA

•	Selective medium for Bacillus cereus is Mannitol Egg yolk Polymyxin Phenol red Agar.

•	It causes food poisoning associated with Chinese fried rice.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on the genitalia. Darkfield microscopy of the lesion exudate shows in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Syphilis

•	The presence of spirochetes on darkfield microscopy and a painless ulcer are characteristic of primary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: A patient has swollen, painful lymph node. A special stain named Wayson stain shows bipolar staining ("safety pin" appearance) bacteria. What is the most likely vector for this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rat flea

•	Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, exhibits bipolar staining and causes bubonic plague characterized by swollen lymph nodes.

•	It is safety pin appearance.

•	Vector is Rat flea (X.cheopsis)

questions.text: A pathogen isolated from burns wound infection shown in the culture image. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

•	Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gramnegative rod that produces a characteristic green pigment (Pyocyanin) and is commonly associated with wound

questions.text: Hide porter’s disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cutaneous form of anthrax

•	Cutaneous anthrax occurs when humans have direct epidermal contact with B. anthracis spores. 

•	A characteristic papule progresses to vesiculation / ulceration and subsequently to black eschar and central necrosis, all at the original site of inoculation. 

•	Malignant pustule and Hide porters disease are the manifestations of cutaneous anthrax.

questions.text: Inclusion bodies present in trachoma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HalberstaedterProwazek  (HP) bodies

•	HalberstaedterProwazek  (HP) bodies present in C. trachomatis,

•	LevinthalCole Lillie (LCL)bodies present in C.psittaci and 

•	Henderson – Peterson Bodies present in Molluscum contagiosum.

•	Migaywa’s granulocorpuscles present in LGV

questions.text: A 75yearold patient develops diarrhea 5 days after starting antibiotic treatment for a serious staphylococcal infection. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clostrioides difficile

•	Clostrioides difficile has been shown to be the major causative agent of  pseudomembranous colitis, which causes diarrhea that most commonly starts after 3 to 4 days of antibiotic administration.

•	Pseudo membranous Colitis after antibiotics like Clindamycin and 3rd Gen cephalosporins.

•	Toxins: A (Enterotoxin) &   B (Cytotoxin)

•	DOC : Fidaxomicin

questions.text: Vietnam timebomb causing organism is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

B. pseudomallei

•	It is otherwise called Whitmore bacillus

•	Causative agent of melidiosis  Glanders like disease, 

•	Motile, Zoonotic  rodents

•	Humans  Pulmonary infections like TB, lymphadenopathy

choices.text: It is a facultative, intracellular parasite.

questions.text: All the following are characteristics of Legionella EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It causes granulomatous lung infection.

•	Legionella causes a fibrinopurulent pneumonia, not a granulomatous pulmonary infection.

•	It is a weakly gramnegative, facultative, intracellular parasite found in streams and airconditioning cooling tanks and is both catalase and oxidase positive.

•	Selective Medium is BCYE agar

questions.text: A previously healthy 8monthold infant presents with apparent upper body weakness including droopy eyes, head lag, drooling, and inability to sit unassisted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Botulism

•	This case is a classic description of infant botulism. 

•	The disease, although rare, is associated with ingestion of honey 

•	Spores contaminate honey and germinate in infant’s GI tract; neurotoxin blocks acetylcholine release, causes constipation and “floppy baby.”

•	The other symptoms of botulism are diffuse, flaccid paralysis, visual disturbances including diplopia (double vision), and speech difficulty (dysarthria).

•	None of the other choices are associated with these disease manifestations.

questions.text: The patient came with a soft, painful genital ulcer.  Gram stain shows gram negative rods arranged in a school of fish pattern. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haemophilus ducreyi

•	Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, characterized by painful genital ulcers and gramnegative rods in a school of fish pattern.

•	Safety pin appearance.

choices.text: Inhibits the release of Acetyl choline
Inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine

questions.text: A patient presents with severe muscle spasms and difficulty swallowing after a puncture wound. Gram stain of wound exudate shows gram positive rods. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine.

•	It’s a case of tetanus caused by C.tetani.

•	MoA of toxin in inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine 

•	Causes spastic paralysis.

questions.text: The patient presents with fever, jaundice, and red eyes. Microscopy shown a spirochete with a flexible, corkscrew shape. What is the gold standard diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MAT

•	It’s a case of Leptospirosis  caused by Leptospira, a spirochete with a corkscrew shape, and presents with fever, jaundice, and red eyes.

•	Gold standard test is Microscopic agglutination test (MAT)

questions.text: A 50yearold man presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and bloody diarrhea. Stool culture grows a gram negative, gull wing shaped bacterium that is oxidase positive. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Campylobacter jejuni

•	Campylobacter jejuni is a gram negative, gullwing shaped bacterium that is oxidase positive and a common cause of gastroenteritis.

•	Microaerophilic and exhibits darting motility

questions.text: Satellitism is exhibited by which organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

H. influenzae

•	Satellitism exhibited by H. influenzae.

•	It is due to factor V

questions.text: All the following Atypical Mycobacteria belongs to Photochromogens except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

M. celatum

•	M. celatum belongs to Scotochromogen.

questions.text: All the following are associated with neonatal meningitis Except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meningococci

•	Neonatal meningitis commonly caused by Listeria, GBS, E. coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text: Most common cause of Atypical pneumonia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

M. pneumoniae

•	Most common cause of atypical pneumonia is Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

•	It is otherwise known as walking pneumoniae.

questions.text: A patient presents with watery diarrhea, dehydration, and rice water stools. Stool culture grows a gram negative, comma shaped bacterium. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vibrio cholerae

•	Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, characterized by rice water stools and a gram negative, comma shaped appearance.

questions.text: A patient presented with a typical rash with the history of tick bite shown in the image. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Borrelia burgdorferi

•	Borrelia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease, which presents with erythema migrans and is often described as a "bull'seye" rash.

•	Vector is tick.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical sign of bacterial meningitis on cerebrospinal fluid analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Normal glucose level

•	Bacterial meningitis presents with decreased glucose level and increased protein level.

•	Polymorphonuclear cells also present.

questions.text: A 25yearold woman presents with a painful vesicular rash localized to the right side of her trunk. She reports a history of chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for her current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Varicellazoster virus

•	The patient’s presentation is consistent with herpes zoster (shingles), which is caused by the reactivation of the varicellazoster virus, the same virus that causes chickenpox.

questions.text: A 30yearold man presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes. Paul Bunnel test is positive. Which virus is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EpsteinBarr virus (EBV)  

•	The patient’s symptoms and positive heterophile antibody test are characteristic of infectious mononucleosis, which is most commonly caused by EpsteinBarr virus.

questions.text: A 6yearold child presents with a "slapped cheek" rash on the face and a lacy red rash on the body. Which virus is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Parvovirus B19  

•	The described rash is characteristic of erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, which is caused by Parvovirus B19

questions.text: A child presents with a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that started on the face and spread downward. Small white spots are visible on the buccal mucosa. Which virus is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Measles virus  

•	The presentation of a maculopapular rash starting at the hairline, along with Koplik spots in the mouth, is characteristic of measles, caused by the measles virus.

questions.text: A newborn presents with microcephaly and intracranial calcifications as shown in the image. The mother had a mild febrile illness during the first trimester of pregnancy. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Zika virus  

•	Zika virus infection during pregnancy can cause congenital Zika syndrome, which includes microcephaly and intracranial calcifications.

questions.text: A 28yearold woman presents with multiple cauliflowerlike lesions on her external genitalia. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Human papillomavirus (HPV)  

•	Condylomata acuminata (genital warts) are caused by certain strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly types 6 and 11.

questions.text: A 4yearold child presents with a fever, sore throat, and vesicular rash on the palms and soles. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coxsackievirus A16  

•	Hand, foot, and mouth disease is commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16, presenting with a vesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. She reports a history of chronic hepatitis B infection. Which virus is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

•	Chronicity seen in Hepatitis B and C viruses.

questions.text: A 12yearold child presents with swelling and tenderness in the parotid glands. The parents report that the child has not received the MMR vaccine. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mumps virus  

•	The swelling and tenderness in the parotid glands are characteristic of mumps, especially in an unvaccinated child.

questions.text: Most common cause of viral myocarditis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coxsackie B virus

•	Most common cause of viral myocarditis is Coxsackie B virus

choices.text: Single stranded RNA with positive sense
Double stranded RNA with negative sense
Double stranded RNA with positive sense
Single stranded RNA with negative sense

questions.text: Find the true statement regarding Rabies virus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Single stranded RNA with negative sense

•	Rabies virus is ssRNA with negative sense, Enveloped and helical symmetry.

•	Bullet shaped virus possess G surface protein

questions.text: Vector for JEV is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Culex mosquito

•	Vector for Japanese Encephalitis virus is Culex mosquito.

questions.text: Serological marker present is HBV vaccination is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

AntiHBsAg

•	Presence of AntiHBsAg alone indicates Vaccination.

questions.text: What is p24 in HIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nucleocapsid antigen

•	P24 antigen denotes Nucleocapsid antigen in HIV.

•	P17 – Matrix protein

questions.text: All enveloped viruses except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HAV

•	Hepatitis A and E viruses are non-enveloped.

questions.text: Which of the following dermatophyte genera infects hair, skin, and nails?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trichophyton

•	Trichophyton species infect hair, skin, or nails, making it one of the primary dermatophytes.

questions.text: Which test is used to demonstrate encapsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in cerebrospinal fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

India Ink Preparation

•	India Ink Preparation is used to detect encapsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is dimorphic and can cause systemic mycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Histoplasma capsulatum

•	Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing systemic mycosis.

questions.text: What is the causative agent of mycetoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Madurella mycetomatis

•	Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection caused by fungi such as Madurella mycetomatis .

questions.text: Which fungus gives germ tube test positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Candida dublinensis

•	Germ tube test positive in C. albicans and C. dublinensis

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent of relapse in malaria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Plasmodium vivax

•	Malaria is caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium.

•	Relapse is seen in P. vivax due to hypnozoites

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for the parasite Schistosoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Snail

•	Snails act as intermediate hosts for Schistosoma species, where larval development occurs.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is transmitted by the tsetse fly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trypanosoma brucei

•	Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African sleeping sickness, is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.text: Which protozoan parasite causes amoebic dysentery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Entamoeba histolytica

•	Entamoeba histolytica is the causative agent of amebic dysentery

questions.text: Which of the following parasites causes river blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Onchocerca volvulus

•	Onchocerca volvulus, transmitted by blackflies, is the causative agent of river blindness.

questions.text: What is the definitive host for Toxoplasma gondii?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cat

•	Cats are the definitive hosts for Toxoplasma gondii, where sexual reproduction of the parasite occurs.

questions.text: Which stage of the Plasmodium life cycle infects red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Merozoite

•	Merozoites are the stage of Plasmodium that infects red blood cells.

questions.text: What is the primary mode of transmission for Giardia lamblia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fecal-oral route

•	Giardia lamblia is primarily transmitted through the fecaloral route, often via contaminated water.

questions.text: Which helminth is known as the "whipworm"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trichuris trichiura

•	Trichuris trichiura is commonly known as the whipworm due to its whiplike shape.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic stage of Enterobius vermicularis in human infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Egg

•	The diagnostic stage for Enterobius vermicularis, or pinworm, is the egg, which can be found around the anal region.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is transmitted through contaminated water and causes severe diarrhea in PLHIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cryptosporidium parvum

•	Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes severe diarrhea and is transmitted through contaminated water.

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for Taenia saginata?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cow

•	The intermediate host for Taenia saginata, the beef tapeworm, is cattle.

questions.text: What is the common name for Ascaris lumbricoides?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Roundworm

•	Ascaris lumbricoides is commonly known as the roundworm.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cestode infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Taeniasis

•	Taeniasis is a cestode infection caused by Taenia species, such as Taenia saginata and Taenia solium.

questions.text: Which helminth infection is commonly associated with anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hookworm infection

•	Hookworm infection, caused by Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus, is commonly associated with anemia due to blood loss.
